instruction: How do I connect to the compute cluster via SSH?
output: You will need to set up a WashU VPN to access compute1 before using SSH. Once that is done, open a terminal prompt and type `ssh wustlkey@compute1-client-1.ris.wustl.edu`, substituting your wustlkey. You may use your normal WUSTL password. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/compute-quick-start.html#connecting-via-ssh)

instruction: How do I start a job on the compute platform?
output: To launch a precompiled docker image, one uses bsub. An example bsub command would be `bsub -Is -G compute-group -q queue -a 'docker(application)'`, which opens a given application in the given queue in interactive mode. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-compute-103.html)

instruction: What is RIS?

instruction: How do I monitor my jobs in Open OnDemand?

instruction: How do I connect to the HPC system using SSH?
output: To connect to the HPC system using SSH, the user must ensure they are on the WUSTL network or using a VPN, and execute `ssh wustlkey@compute1-client-1.ris.wustl.edu`, replacing "wustlkey" with their own WUSTL key. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-compute-101.html#tools-to-connect-and-move-data)

instruction: What is the structure of the Linux file tree in HPC?
output: The Linux file tree in HPC includes home and scratch directories for each user, and paths must be expressed textually since the CLI does not support GUI-style navigation. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-compute-101.html#tools-to-connect-and-move-data)

instruction: What is scratch?
output: Scratch space is a global temporary space which is periodically deleted to free space. Users should not store the only copy of their data within the scratch partition. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/recipes/ris-compute-storage-volumes.html#compute-policies-scratch)

output: Docker is a tool that allows users to deploy custom software within a self-contained system, preventing interaction or interference between programs (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-docker-workshop.html#what-is-docker)

instruction: What is a container?
output: A container is a simulated operating system or computer that has all the necessary tools for running a specific program already inside of it (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-docker-workshop.html#what-is-docker)

instruction: How do I create a Docker container?
output: To create a docker container, you will need an account on Docker Hub. You must then decide on a base operating system, software packages, and boot procedures, and write a corresponding Dockerfile. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-docker-workshop.html#id8)
